name: Dragon Palace
shortDescription: Magnificent underwater palace of the Dragon Kings, repository of cosmic treasures
fullDescription: The Dragon Palace (ÈæçÂÆÆ, L√≥ng G≈çng) is the magnificent underwater realm of the Dragon Kings (L√≥ng W√°ng), located beneath the seas, rivers, and lakes of China. These palaces are described as resplendent structures made of crystal, coral, and precious gems, filled with treasures including magical weapons, pearls, and the tools that control the weather. Each of the four Dragon Kings rules from their palace in one of the four seas (East, South, West, North). The most famous is Ao Guang's palace in the Eastern Sea, visited by Sun Wukong to obtain his legendary staff.

properties.name: Locations
properties.value: Four palaces in the seas of East, South, West, and North

properties.name: Rulers
properties.value: Four Dragon Kings (Ao Guang, Ao Qin, Ao Run, Ao Shun)

properties.name: Structure
properties.value: Crystal and coral palaces with vast treasure chambers

properties.name: Function
properties.value: Dragon realm, weather control center, treasure repository

properties.name: Notable Treasures
properties.value: Ruyi Jingu Bang, Dragon Pearls, magical armor, weather instruments

mythologyContexts.usage: Home of Dragon Kings who control rain, rivers, and seas. Repository of magical weapons and treasures. Site of Sun Wukong's acquisition of the Ruyi Jingu Bang. Represents the power and mystery of water realms

rituals.name: Sun Wukong's Visit
rituals.description: The Monkey King visited Ao Guang's palace and claimed the Ruyi Jingu Bang

rituals.name: Rain Petitions
rituals.description: Mortals and gods petition the Dragon Kings for rain during droughts

rituals.name: Nezha's Rebellion
rituals.description: The young deity Nezha fought and killed Ao Guang's son, causing conflict between heaven and sea

rituals.name: Dragon King Banquets
rituals.description: Elaborate underwater feasts attended by sea creatures and visiting deities

textReferences.context: Sun Wukong's visit to the Dragon Palace and acquisition of his staff
Conflict between Nezha and the Dragon Kings
Descriptions of dragon realms and sea palaces

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The Dragon Palace represents the mysterious depths of water - powerful, life-giving, yet potentially destructive. It symbolizes the hidden treasures of wisdom and power that lie beneath ordinary perception. The palace's magnificence reflects the dragon's yang nature despite dwelling in yin water, showing the complementary balance of opposites.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Dragon Palaces feature prominently in Chinese mythology, literature, and art. They appear in folk tales, temple murals, and festivals. The concept influenced Japanese mythology (Ry≈´g≈´-j≈ç). Dragon King temples throughout China serve as centers for rain petitions and water-related rituals.

japanese.meaning: dragon palace (as in Ry≈´g≈´-j≈ç, Urashima Tar≈ç tale)

originPoint.description: Four palaces beneath the Four Seas (East, South, West, North); Eastern Sea palace most prominent in literature
originPoint.mythicalLocation: Beneath seas, rivers, and lakes throughout China

firstAttestation.description: Han dynasty texts systematize dragon king mythology; fully developed in Journey to the West (1592 CE)
firstAttestation.source: Han dynasty folklore, Journey to the West

temporal.philosophicalContext: Buddhist-Daoist syncretism; dragon kings as water deities controlling weather and aquatic realms
